source.author: John J. Pipoly III,Jon M. Ricketson

taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek name for a kind of myrtle]

bio:treatment.description: Shrubs or trees, monoecious or dioecious [polygamous], not succulent, [densely pubescent] glabrous. Leaves persistent, alternate, monomorphic; petiole present; blade elliptic, oblong, obovate, or oblanceolate, base attenuate to rounded, margins entire, revolute, apex acute to rounded, often emarginate, surfaces glabrous. Inflorescences lateral (axillary) fascicles [umbels], sessile or subsessile, shorter than petiole; peduncle accrescent, forming short shoot; bracts persistent. Pedicels present [absent]. Flowers [bisexual] unisexual; sepals 4–6, green, calyx lobes triangular to ovate, ± equaling tube; petals [4–]5[–6], corolla green to white or pink, cupuliform to campanulate, lobes longer than tube, apex acute; stamens 4–6; filaments distinct or connate basally (forming tube); staminodes present; stigmas conic, 3–5-lobed. Fruits drupaceous, green to black, globose [subglobose, ellipsoid, ovoid, obovoid, or subovoid]; exocarp somewhat fleshy; endocarp crusty or leathery. Seeds 1, white to black, globose or depressed, usually covered with membranous remnants of placenta.
bio:treatment.discussion: J. J. Pipoly (1991, 1992, 1992b, 1996, 2007) and J. M. Ricketson and Pipoly (1997, 1999) have discussed the circumscription of Myrsine to include Rapanea, among others. Field work has shown that the dioecious plants often have bisexual flowers.
